natural problem: Find the cubic polynomial $p(x)$ such that $p(1) = -7,$ $p(2) = -9,$ $p(3) = -15,$ and $p(4) = -31.$
natural solution: Let $p(x) = ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + d.$  Then from the given information, \begin{align} a + b + c + d &= -7, \\ 8a + 4b + 2c + d &= -9, \\ 27a + 9b + 3c + d &= -15, \\ 64a + 16b + 4c + d &= -31. \end{align}Subtracting the first and second equations, second and third equations, and third and fourth equations, we get

\begin{align} 7a + 3b + c &= -2, \\ 19a + 5b + c &= -6, \\ 37a + 7b + c &= -16. \end{align}Again subtracting the equations in pairs, we get \begin{align} 12a + 2b &= -4, \\ 18a + 2b &= -10. \end{align}Subtracting once more, we get $6a = -6,$ so $a = -1.$  Back-substituting gives us $b = 4,$ $c = -7,$ and $d = -3.$  Therefore, \[p(x) = \boxed{-x^3 + 4x^2 - 7x - 3}.\]

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "p 1 = -7"
and h1 : "p 2 = -9"
and h2 : "p 3 = -15"
and h3 : "p 4 = -31"
shows  "\<forall>x. p x = -x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 - 7 * x - 3"
a_0.formal solution:

 *)
